chapter.title: Accommodations help ensure fair, equitable access to educational services
chapter.content:
Accommodations adjust the manner in which instructional, testing, and employment situations are presented or evaluated without changing the actual standards a student is working toward, so that an individual with learning disabilities can demonstrate his or her knowledge in a fair and equitable fashion.

Accommodations individualize instruction to meet diverse learning levels and are legally mandated. These instructions may include combining oral instruction with visual handouts or reading aloud material that is too difficult for a learner.

In this topic, you will learn the four types of accommodations and the features of effective accommodations.

chapter.title: Four types of accommodations
chapter.content:
There are four main types of accommodations that may be utilized by a company or facility, or in an educational setting. 

  1. Presentation –  A change to the way information is presented.
    Example: A student listens to an audio version of book instead of reading the text. 
  2. Response – A change in the way assignments or tests are completed.
    Example: A student is given an oral exam instead of a written exam.
  3. Scheduling or Timing – A change in the amount of time a student is given to complete tasks or a change to the number or timing of breaks the student is given.
    Example: Allow students fifty percent more time to complete the task (e.g. provide 15 minutes for a 10 minute task. 
  4. Setting– A change in the environment.
    Example: A student is allowed to take a test in a separate room away from other students and potential distractions. 

Later in this course, we will discuss the different types of accommodations in detail.

chapter.title: Features of accommodations
chapter.content:
Accommodations have four key features. 

  1. First, accommodations are individualized to emphasize a person's strengths and work around their weaknesses, as well as the demands of the situation. 
  2. Second, accommodations require documentation from a licensed clinician who is trained to administer diagnostic testing for learning disabilities. This documentation will help determine the needs of the individual and the most appropriate type of accommodation. However, if documentation is unavailable, the instructor should use his or her best judgment to assist the student in class.
  3. Third, accommodations do not interfere with the skill or concept being taught. For instance, if reading decoding is the skill being measured on a test, a person reading the test to the student might not be an acceptable accommodation. However, if science knowledge is the skill being measured on the test, a person reading the test to a student so they can answer the questions might be a reasonable accommodation. 
  4. Fourth, accommodations for documented learning disabilities provide access to a learning environment to which all Americans are entitled. The Legal Right of Access for students with disabilities is derived from several federal laws, including the 14th Amendment, Title VI of the Civil Rights Act, the Equal Opportunity Act of 1974, and the Americans with Disabilities Act.

More Information

More information about accommodations is available on the National Center for Education Outcomes (NCEO) website. NCEO, housed at the University of Minnesota, provides leadership on evidence-based information on inclusive assessments and comprehensive assessment systems. NCEO aims to benefit students with disabilities, English learners, and English learners with disabilities through their efforts to support the implementation of U.S. Department of Education accountability systems. NCEO publications are freely available online, including a comprehensive bibliography of accommodations studies.

chapter.title: Does Hamid need accommodations?
chapter.content:
Our first scenario is about Hamid, a young immigrant. Read Hamid’s story, then determine whether he needs accommodations.

Hamid’s Story

Hamid is taking adult basic education classes to improve his reading skills so he can complete his General Education Development test, regularly referred to as the GED. Hamid emigrated from Iran
when he was five years old. He was diagnosed with a Learning Disability (LD) when in the public schools. Unfortunately, he has no past evaluation documentation from his high school years to provide support for accessing
accommodations on the GED.

Based on the information provided, does Hamid need accommodations?

  1. Yes
  2. No

When you have decided on your answer, advance to the next page for the correct answer and the next question.

chapter.title: Qualification
chapter.content:
Based on Hamid’s earlier diagnosis of a learning disability, he does qualify for accommodations. 

Hamid’s Story

Hamid is taking adult basic education classes to improve his reading skills so he can complete his General Education Development test, regularly referred to as the GED. Hamid emigrated from Iran when he was five years old. He was diagnosed with a Learning Disability (LD) when in the public schools. Unfortunately, he has no past evaluation documentation from his high school years to provide support for accessing accommodations on the GED.

On what basis would Hamid’s ABE teacher provide classroom accommodations?

  1. Clinician assessment
  2. Documentation post-high school
  3. His / her best judgement
  4. None of the above

When you have decided on your answer, advance to the next slide for the correct answer and the next question.

chapter.title: Basis for accommodation
chapter.content:
Hamid has no past evaluation documentation for his learning disability; therefore, the adult basic education teacher must use his or her best judgment when determining if Hamid requires  accommodations.

Hamid's Story

Hamid is taking adult basic education classes to improve his reading skills so he can complete his General Education Development test, regularly referred to as the GED. Hamid emigrated from Iran when he was five years old. He was diagnosed with a Learning Disability (LD) when in the public schools. Unfortunately, he has no past evaluation documentation from his high school years to provide support for accessing accommodations on the GED.

What accommodations would you select for Hamid?

  1. Extra time for instructional and testing situations
  2. A quiet room during testing
  3. Enlarged font size of textbooks
  4. All of the above

Think about your answer, then advance to the next slide.

chapter.title: Potential accommodations
chapter.content:
The correct answer is d, all of the above. Hamid’s participation in classes to improve his reading skills as well as his learning disability suggests that he would benefit from:

  • extra time for instructional and testing situations;
  • a quiet room during testing; and
  • enlarged font size of textbooks for ease of reading.

The majority of adolescents and adults with learning disabilities demonstrate difficulties with the speed of processing literacy tasks (Gregg, 2009). Therefore, recognizing that Hamid has a long history of LD, the ABE teacher might consider providing him extra time on instructional and testing tasks. However, if Hamid requests the accommodation of extra time on a high stakes test such as the GED, he must provide current psychological documentation.
